#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:16:46] <T0rin> saw my name, didnt understand much!
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:18:04] <T0rin> most pwk mobs just pwk random people, not buffer
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:18:26] <T0rin> so the other day, angelique says that mob pwk just does a ton more damage, but I think that is bullshit
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:18:38] <T0rin> which is why it kills where player pwk sucks
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:22:24] <T0rin> well yep, angelique was right
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:22:28] <T0rin> it just does damage
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:23:20] <T0rin> haha
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:23:24] <T0rin> well its pretty high
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:23:29] <T0rin> so it starts with mob level
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:24:34] <T0rin> min(2500,4000)=2500, right?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:25:33] <T0rin> ok it is
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:25:34] <T0rin> anyways
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:26:02] <T0rin> if mob level is less than 50, pwk damage from mob is 2500
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:26:10] <T0rin> if mob is greater than 50, it is mob level * 50
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:26:18] <T0rin> so level 100 mob, min damage is 5000
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:26:19] <T0rin> THEN
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:26:37] <T0rin> if mob elvel is > 50, it adds another 250*(mob level-50)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:26:52] <T0rin> so for level 100 mob it adds another 12500 damage
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:26:59] <T0rin> so 17500 damage so far
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:27:09] <T0rin> min
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:27:55] <T0rin> heh
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:28:00] <T0rin> so if you have less hp than that, you just die
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:28:10] <T0rin> well it does that damage to you and you die
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:28:18] <T0rin> if you have enough hp above min..
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:28:26] <T0rin> it checks if your hp is 3*min
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:30:50] <T0rin> well if hp is 3*min, you get a severe damage reduction on it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:31:10] <T0rin> damage = min - (hp-min)/2
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:31:32] <T0rin> so reduces damage by 50% of the difference between min and your hp
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:31:42] <T0rin> if you have more hp than min but not 3x..
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:32:32] <T0rin> oh that is if you have more hp than min but not 3x
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:32:43] <T0rin> but if you do have more than 3x it does 1 damage
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:32:56] <T0rin> ok so less hp than min, you take min
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:33:12] <T0rin> more hp than min but less than 3*min, you take min-(diff between min and your hp/2)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:33:20] <T0rin> and if hp is > 3*min, you take 1
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:33:35] <T0rin> oh also, sanc and invul add 2x modifier to hp
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:33:49] <T0rin> so curman with 10,000 hp and sanc/invul should count as 40,000 hp
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:33:57] <T0rin> and should survive pwk from almost any mob
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:34:10] <T0rin> but that isnt true, is it?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:34:47] <T0rin> and for pcs casting it, is only 4000 damage min
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:34:50] <T0rin> at emp
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:35:07] <T0rin> so can only kill tiny mobs
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 10, 16:35:20] <T0rin> actually min is just damage, there is no max :P

#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:06:26] <Torin|> while execute < skill_execute: stab, execute+20
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:06:31] <Torin|> execute starts at 115
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:06:37] <Torin|> for dress
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:07:00] <Torin|> actually is while random(1-execute)<skill_execute
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:08:10] <Torin|> 70 stabs wouldnt lag me out :)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:08:46] <Torin|> 7.5 is average stab with 180 execute
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:09:14] <Torin|> about 8.1 with 190
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:09:37] <Torin|> some hard ass diminishing returns with exe skill
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:09:57] <Torin|> hah
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:10:55] <Torin|> execute = 115;
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:10:55] <Torin|>   while(number(1,execute) < skill_execute){
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:10:55] <Torin|>     execute += 20;   
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:10:55] <Torin|>     hit(ch, victim, SKILL_BACKSTAB);
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:10:55] <Torin|>     return;
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:11:09] <Torin|>     }
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:21] <Torin|>     numbers = 0;
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:21] <Torin|>     execute = 135;
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:21] <Torin|>     while(number(1,execute-GET_INT(ch)) < skill_execute){
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:21] <Torin|>       numbers = numbers+2;
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:21] <Torin|>       execute += 23+numbers;
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:24] <Torin|>       hit(ch, victim, SKILL_STING);
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:26] <Torin|>         return;
#Philocommands.log:[2009 03 27, 23:12:29] <Torin|>       }

#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:41:42] <Torin|_> asterix is hardcore into v4
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:41:57] <Torin|_> we've been talking about details for hours now
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:53:01] <Torin|_> we've been going over items mostly
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:53:16] <Torin|_> totally brand new item system
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:53:50] <Torin|_> items will have a type (to determine slot), a subtype (to determine amount of material used to make it), and a material
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:08] <Torin|_> size is determined by subtype
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:09] <Torin|_> lets say a short sword
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:09] <Torin|_> type: sword, subtype: short
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:09] <Torin|_> short type sword is size 2
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:15] <Torin|_> if made of mithril, it is worth 20,000 gold and weighs 2
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:27] <Torin|_> enchantability is an attribute of material
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:45] <Torin|_> sa damage is determined by material type and weapon subtype
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:51] <Torin|_> sa longsword is d8 by default
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:57:58] <Torin|_> mithril longsword is 3d8
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:58:05] <Torin|_> masterwork mithril longsword is 3d9
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:58:11] <Torin|_> novice mithril longsword is 3d7
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:59:15] <Torin|_> when forging a short sword, you need 2 units of whatever material you want to make it out of
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:59:21] <Torin|_> which also determines its value
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:59:29] <Torin|_> size is an attribute of the item subtype
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 21:59:42] <Torin|_> full plate would be type: body armor, subtype: full plate
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:00:02] <Torin|_> might take 10 units of material, where a breastplate would be type: body armor, subtype: breastplate and only take 4 units of material
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:01:03] <Torin|_> if mithril weighs 1 pound per unit, a mithril full plate would weigh 10 pounds, but a mithril breastplate would onl weigh 4
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:01:50] <Torin|_> sa AC is also determined by size and material
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:06:09] <Torin|_> every material woudl have different properties
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:06:14] <Torin|_> some materials even decay
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:06:28] <Torin|_> also some materials have a natural slaying property on weapons
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:06:45] <Torin|_> a silver weapon could potentially slay vampires, but you need a generic "slaying" enchant to bring out its potential
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:07:00] <Torin|_> a regular cold iron long sword would not slay demons, but a slaying enchanted cold iron long sword would
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:24:56] <Torin|_> slaying will be a component though of material
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:25:07] <Torin|_> so if you want a demon slaying weapon, you make it from cold iron
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:25:19] <Torin|_> traetar is goign to drop a +6 darksteel scimitar of soul draining
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 12, 22:25:32] <Torin|_> called Soultaker!

#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:27:08] <Torin|> yeah, thats the thing though, a brand new mud needs a lot of areas
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:28:02] <Torin|> so you heard all the details about the v4 item system?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:28:16] <Torin|> yeah from the day before yesterday
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:28:40] <Torin|> heh
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:30:23] <Torin|> soultaker was just 1 example
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:30:32] <Torin|> so I'll go over it again
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:30:40] <Torin|> every item has a material and type
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:30:55] <Torin|> like long sword made of steel
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:31:07] <Torin|> every long sword is of a specified damage range, like 2d15
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:31:20] <Torin|> the material adds bonuses, like steel is +0 +2
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:31:37] <Torin|> +0 is # of dice (i.e. 2 for longsword) and +2 is dice size (i.e. 15 for long sword)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:31:45] <Torin|> so a steel long sword is 2d17
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:31:58] <Torin|> darksteel is +1 +4
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:32:04] <Torin|> a darksteel long sword is 3d19
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:32:33] <Torin|> each material has its own properties, mainly how much 1 unit of that material weighs, and how much it costs
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:32:39] <Torin|> darksteel is 25,000 gold per unit
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:32:46] <Torin|> a long sword takes 3 units of material to make
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:33:00] <Torin|> and darksteel weighs 2 pounds per unit
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:33:15] <Torin|> so a darksteel longsword is 3d19, costs 75,000 in darksteel and weighs 6 pounds
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:33:41] <Torin|> darksteel also inherently slays good, but requires an enchantment to bring that slaying effect out
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:33:57] <Torin|> mostly all materials slay something inherently
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:34:08] <Torin|> there is a generic enchantment "slaying" that can be added to any weapon
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:34:13] <Torin|> brings out the slaying potential of teh weapon
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:34:26] <Torin|> a few materials will slay regardless of having that enchantment
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:34:56] <Torin|> now, the basic item enchantment system is based on 3rd edition d&d
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:35:03] <Torin|> enhancement bonuses and other bonuses
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:35:16] <Torin|> an enhancemetn bonus is +X damroll and +X hitroll
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:35:23] <Torin|> shut up and listen
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:36:20] <Torin|> se
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:36:20] <Torin|> c
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:37:10] <Torin|> ok
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:37:21] <Torin|> so every item can have an enhancement bonus
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:37:25] <Torin|> for waepons its +X damroll and hitroll
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:37:35] <Torin|> for armor its +AC
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:37:44] <Torin|> now, every material has an enchantment limit
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:37:55] <Torin|> the more exotic materials can be enchanted higher than others
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:38:02] <Torin|> darksteel for instance has an enchantment limit of 15
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:38:16] <Torin|> the slaying enchantment costs 2 points
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:38:25] <Torin|> a +8 enhancement bonus costs 8 points
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:38:31] <Torin|> a +4 enhancement bonus costs 4 points
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:38:44] <Torin|> the soul draining enchantment costs 3 points
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:38:56] <Torin|> soul draining enchantment is basically the soultaker spec
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:39:05] <Torin|> it makes any item enchanted with it anti-good anti-neutral
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:39:20] <Torin|> soultaker is a +8 darksteel scimitar enchanted with slaying and soul draining
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:39:39] <Torin|> 13/15 enchantment points are already used
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:39:46] <Torin|> meaning, you can further improve soultaker
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:39:57] <Torin|> you could for instance use 1 point to add a 1d6 fire damage to the weapon
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:40:16] <Torin|> you could use the remaining 2 points to increase teh enhancement bonus from +8 to +10
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:40:23] <Torin|> making it a +10 darksteel scimitar with slaying and sould raining
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:40:25] <Torin|> draining*
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:40:29] <Torin|> 15/15 enchantment points
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:40:41] <Torin|> enhancement bonuses are limtied to +10 on any item
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:40:54] <Torin|> and there will be a LOT of different enchantments
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:41:19] <Torin|> now, one thing to keep in mind, is that this system is in place not only to limit the power of items, but allow players to craft and enchant any weapon or item the way they want
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:41:39] <Torin|> if for instance, Malus drops a +5 darksteel suit of plate mail
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:41:47] <Torin|> you could take that suit and further enchant it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:42:02] <Torin|> but maybe you dont want +5, you only want +3 on it and you want to use the other 12 enchantment points for other enchantments
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:42:25] <Torin|> you could have someone with the forge skill take raw darksteel (7 units for full plate) and forge a new set of darksteel plate mail
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:42:41] <Torin|> and then enchant it how you want it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:42:55] <Torin|> finding pre-enchanted items on mobs will save you the trouble of forging items and doing some enchantments to them
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:43:10] <Torin|> so you can not only take mob loaded eq and further enchant it (if it has enchantment room)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:43:16] <Torin|> or you canf orge the exact same items from scratch
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:43:38] <Torin|> you can have someone forge a darksteel scimitar, and enchatn it yourself up to +8 enhancemetn bonus and add slaying and soul draining to it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:43:55] <Torin|> the limti system is effectively gone
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:44:10] <Torin|> items are limited by their enchantment limit, which is a property of material
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:45:03] <Torin|> now, all weapon enchants are mostly stuff that would improve damage or critical chance
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:45:19] <Torin|> there will be a few things you can add, like affects
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:45:28] <Torin|> a haste affect, a detect invis affect
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:45:52] <Torin|> stuff like that, but all of these enchantments will require materials found aroudn the game, most of the better enchants will require material components dropped by high level stuff at low rates
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:46:11] <Torin|> it effective lets you design your own items, every item, from scratch, given enough time, skill and materials
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:46:16] <Torin|> effectively
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:46:34] <Torin|> or you can improve on existing items in whatever way you like
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:47:19] <Torin|> armor will have other enchants not available to weapons, like stat boosting affects (stats will be huge in v4), hp and mana bonuses, and a variety of "spec" effects
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:47:38] <Torin|> adding a soul draining enchant to a weapon gives it the soul drain spec of soultaker
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:48:16] <Torin|> adding a "fortification" enchant to a piece of armor will reduce your chances of someone getting a critical attack on you, or using any skill that relies on someone being able to be critically attacked (like backstab, circle, etc.)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:48:32] <Torin|> basically, a partial immunity to critical attacks
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:48:40] <Torin|> in v4, critical attacks will happen for every char
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:48:49] <Torin|> people with the critical attack skill will just have a higher chance
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:48:59] <Torin|> and it will be double or triple or quadruple damage or more, depending on the weapon used
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:49:08] <Torin|> each weapon has a critical chance and critical multiplier
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:49:28] <Torin|> longsword is double damage and 5% chance
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:50:06] <Torin|> someone with the critical attack skill could effectively boost that by an additional 10%
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:50:20] <Torin|> someone with the critical strike skill could effectively boost the multiplier to quadruple damage
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:50:38] <Torin|> some classes will only get one of those 2 skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:50:45] <Torin|> some will get both, but not be able to train  them as high
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 14, 17:51:11] <Torin|> some will get neither, and just rely on the base stats of teh weapon and any enchants that might modify that

#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:31:19] <Torin|> so when you reach the end of your path
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:31:27] <Torin|> you will gain access to your tarnsformation skill
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:31:35] <Torin|> be it transformation into a dragon or whatever you transform into

#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:31:47] <Torin|> and as such will be restricted by room size

#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:31:59] <Torin|> smaller, not restricted
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:32:12] <Torin|> each form is a reward for a different ranking path
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:32:48] <Torin|> when you get to teh end of your ranking path and unlock the transformation skill, you gain a new stat, Endurance
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:33:17] <Torin|> Endurance cannot be meta'd, it is derived from all of your other stats, str/con/wis/int/dex
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:34:04] <Torin|> yes it changes when your stats do
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:34:11] <Torin|> it also increases as your form level increases
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:34:38] <Torin|> endurance is used for 1 purpose, when you change into your special form, it starts to drain your endurance
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:35:36] <Torin|> no, it wont be useless
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:35:46] <Torin|> the more you use your form, the more form levels you get, and the more endurance you get
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:35:58] <Torin|> teh more you increase your stats, the more endurance you get, the more you can use your form
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:36:30] <Torin|> form power will be derived from your equpiment and your stats
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:36:48] <Torin|> each form will vary when you use the transformation skill, and will be in many ways based on your equipment
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:37:17] <Torin|> if you wear a bunch of heavy armor, when you transform, your special form will also have heavy armor
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:37:33] <Torin|> your form's natural armor will also determine how well your form skills perform
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:37:50] <Torin|> if your special form can dodge, and has heavy armor, dodging in heavy armor sucks, and will be penalized
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:38:09] <Torin|> so if you have light armor, when you transform into this form that dodges, your dodge ability will be boosted
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:38:29] <Torin|> rather than training armor and claws and bite and shit, those things will be determined base on your equipment
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:38:45] <Torin|> experience earned while in form will go to your form levels
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:39:08] <Torin|> no, it might start at a few minutes, and might end up at a few hours the more endurancve you gain
#Philocommands.log:[2009 05 22, 19:39:43] <Torin|> there is no cooldown

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:04:42] <Torin|_> like when you circle
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:04:53] <Torin|_> it checks to see if the mob has the "distracted" flag
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:05:08] <Torin|_> which can be added by various skills, such as warcry, stun, etc.
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:05:19] <Torin|_> if it has a distracted flag, the move silently check for circle is a success
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:05:30] <Torin|_> if no distracted flag, then it just makes a skill check on the guy doing the circle
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:05:39] <Torin|_> if fail, then skill fails, if success, it keeps going
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:05:43] <Torin|_> just a lot of checks
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 06, 18:06:06] <Torin|_> but if I have to make a new skill allow it to help circle, I just code that 1 skill to add distracted flag

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:47:41] <Torin|> and anything you already learned in your old subclass, you would still know, just not be able to use

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:48:47] <Torin|> basically 1 process for quitting the subclass and another process for joining whatever subclass you want
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:49:02] <Torin|> along witht he required actions to actually change your alignment

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:50:36] <Torin|> need to be good and a member of good subclass to train good subclass abilities

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:52:35] <Torin|> there is middle ground that alignment categories share
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:53:03] <Torin|> kind of like neutral evil, true neutral, neutral good
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:53:09] <Torin|> all neutral alignments
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 19:53:30] <Torin|> well alignments control what subclass you can join, and what subclass skills you can use

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:01:25] <Torin|> subclasses were moslty meant as a way to specialize core abilities and/or add non-core abilities
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:03:13] <Torin|> a mix of specialization and multi-classing
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:03:30] <Torin|> some more of each than others
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:03:47] <Torin|> arcane scholar is mostly multi-classing, where battlemage subclasses for example are almost purely specialization
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:03:56] <Torin|> arcane scholar is the good align wizard subclass
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:04:33] <Torin|> it just depends on how multi-classing-ish I want a subclass to be
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:04:47] <Torin|> if a class is "hybrid enough", then subclasses are mostly specialization
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:05:11] <Torin|> like in the case of battlemage and woodsman
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:06:30] <Torin|> generally I am trying to design subclasses to be able to use all core skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:06:58] <Torin|> a few skills, like archery, wont be useful if you dont want to use them, some core skills are mutually exclusive of each other
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:07:12] <Torin|> more there as options
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:07:24] <Torin|> but subclasses should be able to use all core skills and spells
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:07:42] <Torin|> subclasses should enhance certain ones, but should not make them useless
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:08:08] <Torin|> thats why they are core skills/spells
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:08:23] <Torin|> think of it like a cake
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:08:37] <Torin|> the core class is the cake itself, and the subclass is the icing and sprinkles
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 09, 21:09:18] <Torin|> warrior might be a vanilla cake, righteous defender might be vanilla icing and sprinkles, kensai might be chocolate icing and cherries and mercenary might be strawberry icing and candles

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 19:55:58] <Torin|_> !help
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 19:56:03] <Torin|_> m group all
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 19:56:40] <Torin|_> well, its nto really enough that everyone's eq IS different, it needs to appear different at a glance as well
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 19:57:34] <Torin|_> maybe do a prefix suffix system based on enhancement enchants and most powerful non-enhancement enchant
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 19:57:49] <Torin|_> as mostly every item, or at least very many will have enhancement bonuses
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 19:57:58] <Torin|_> ah yeah
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 19:58:27] <Torin|_> enhancement is a type of enchant, that provides hitroll and damroll to weapons and Armor to armor, and saving throws to non-armor
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:00:19] <Torin|_> items also have quality
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:00:23] <Torin|_> seems I need to make that post :P
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:00:36] <Torin|_> quality is a value attached to an item when it is crafted
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:00:58] <Torin|_> basically, shows how well the crafted made the item,a nd is a representation of the crafter's skill vs difficulty of the item and material
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:01:19] <Torin|_> each item subtype (breastplate, great helm, short sword) has a difficulty #, and each material has a difficulty #
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:01:42] <Torin|_> when those numbers are combined, you get a crafting difficulty, like maybe a darksteel breastplate requires 80 difficulty
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:02:08] <Torin|_> if someone had a crafting skill of 80, they could make one, but it would be low quality, i.e. giving -1 AC modifier to the item
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:02:27] <Torin|_> if they had skill of 90, they could craft it at average quality, or normal AC
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:02:37] <Torin|_> and if they had skill of 100, they could craft it at high quality, +1 AC
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:02:47] <Torin|_> +1 AC being to base amount
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:03:30] <Torin|_> well no, but an armor with 18 AC is not as good as one with 20
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:03:41] <Torin|_> so +1 base AC would take it from 18 to 19
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:03:50] <Torin|_> AC as an affect would want to be negative
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:04:02] <Torin|_> enhancement bonus applies AC as an affect to items
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:04:21] <Torin|_> enhancement bonus 8 would apply -8 AC modifier to a piece of armor
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:04:39] <Torin|_> well, maybe that's how we'll do it :P
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:05:51] <Torin|_> no, enchanting has nothing to do with the quality of an item
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:06:02] <Torin|_> and quality just is a modifier to the item's base stats
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:06:12] <Torin|_> yes
#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:06:45] <Torin|_> you could enchant a lower quality item made of a more enchantable material to make it better than q high quality item of the same type made out of a lesser enchantable amterial

#Philocommands.log:[2009 07 14, 20:07:48] <Torin|_> so a crappy item made out of a good material is still worth something

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:22:43] <Torin|_> heh, what he told me was definitely out there
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:23:07] <Torin|_> kind of like, multiple layers of reality resting on top of each other
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:23:15] <Torin|_> physical, spiritual and mental
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:23:22] <Torin|_> essentially different manifestations of the world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:23:39] <Torin|_> where items, npcs, structures vary from reality to reality
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:24:13] <Torin|_> you could leave your physical body and project your spiritual body onto the spiritual plane, and wander around there
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:24:24] <Torin|_> encounters NPCs on teh spiritual plane that are not present on the physical
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:24:39] <Torin|_> method of combat differs from reality to reality, the effect of spells and skills is different
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:25:12] <Torin|_> some npcs could exist in multiple realities at once, fighting a monster that exists in multiple, you would have to fight them in multiple
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:25:45] <Torin|_> even the idea of player races that exist in multiple realities at once, that you have to essentially login to the mud twice to play both realities of the character at tehj same time
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:26:45] <Torin|_> your being is composed of a physical body linked to a spiritual body, held together and controlled by your mental power
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:27:11] <Torin|_> when you project your spiritual body onto the spiritual reality, your physical body basically goes into a kind of hibernation/stasis
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:27:28] <Torin|_> where your spiritual body/mind roam around teh spiritual plane
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:27:50] <Torin|_> you would basically have to go back to wher eyou left your physical body to re-enter it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:28:05] <Torin|_> some people would have the ability to transport their physical body in teh world where their spiritual body is, and rejoin in a new spot
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:28:33] <Torin|_> so you could leave your physical body, walk through where a door was on the physical plane, and teleport your physical body to where your sprituial body is, and rejoin it back on the physical plane, past the door
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:29:13] <Torin|_> you would have stats for different realities
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:29:29] <Torin|_> you could attack someone mentally, or physically, or spiritually, assuming they have presences there
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:29:41] <Torin|_> some NPCs might not have minds, might just be instinctual creatures, you could not attack them mentally
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:29:49] <Torin|_> some creatures have no spirit, and only exist on the physical plane
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:29:59] <Torin|_> some creatures are only spirits, and exist only on the spiritual
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:30:42] <Torin|_> multiple ways of dying, if you were projecting your spirit to teh spiritual plane, and your spirit was killed there, it would be severed from your body, and you would have to have it re-attached before your mind could re-enter your body
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:30:55] <Torin|_> basically when you die, your mind is separated from your body
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:30:59] <Torin|_> and floats in limbo
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:31:16] <Torin|_> your mind is responsible for communication, so you can communicate to living beings
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:31:40] <Torin|_> a player could fix your body, re-attach your spirit to your physical body, whatever it took to make your body ready to be re-entered
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:32:02] <Torin|_> if you died physically, someone would have to repair your physical body for you to re-enter
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:32:12] <Torin|_> if you died spiritually, someone would have to re-attach your spirit to your body
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:32:51] <Torin|_> the mental reality would not be the same kind of reality, it does not have a world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:33:03] <Torin|_> would work like psionics if you know about psionics
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:33:16] <Torin|_> basically, manifesting effects int eh physical or spiritual world based on your mental abilities
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:33:33] <Torin|_> your mind would be the source of another kind of magic
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:33:45] <Torin|_> there would be normal magic, that you cast with magical energy, magic spells, taht sort of thing
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:33:56] <Torin|_> then mental abilities that produce magical effects, but originate from your mind
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:34:18] <Torin|_> you could also attack people mentally, aim to destroy their minds, which would then crippple their physical or spiritual body
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:34:35] <Torin|_> you can also be killed that way
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:34:56] <Torin|_> several ways to die, and when you die in 1, you die in all
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:35:18] <Torin|_> the body, spirit and mind are always connected, when one of those connections is severed, you are dead
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:35:32] <Torin|_> and have to reconnect the appropriate thing to become alive again
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:36:43] <Torin|_> exploring the world would be a combination of physical and spiritual interactions
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:37:25] <Torin|_> there might be a place you need to get to on the physical world, that the path to only exists in teh spiritual world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:37:40] <Torin|_> or a place that only exists in the spiritual world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:37:58] <Torin|_> also, the idea that most NPCs would have a spirit, and if you go around killing their physical bodies for exp
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:38:05] <Torin|_> their spirits are collecting, unkilled in teh spiritual reality
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:38:31] <Torin|_> their spirits would not be able to directly interact with you, but would have an affect on the physical world, and the more spirits that piled up, the more of an affect it would have
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:38:56] <Torin|_> people with certain abilities would have to keep the spirit world undr control
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:39:17] <Torin|_> killing excess spirits
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 19:39:38] <Torin|_> also talked briefly about a classless system

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:12:51] <Torin|_> the main purpose of the system is to diversify combat and diversify exploring the world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:13:02] <Torin|_> when you come into a new area, you have to think about it from several perspectives
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:13:14] <Torin|_> its not just abotu walking around, getting options, unlocking doors, that sort of thing
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:13:28] <Torin|_> you have to understand that you will transverse the different realities in order to make i tthrough
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:13:36] <Torin|_> that there might be a task you have to accomplish on one reality vs another
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:14:20] <Torin|_> and not everyone will be capable of going back and forth either
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:14:55] <Torin|_> generally, most everything will have a physical reality aspect to it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:15:08] <Torin|_> so even just starting out, when you are strictly limited to the physical reality, you will have stuff
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:15:24] <Torin|_> spiritual reality starts to come into play in intermediate levels, and for the people who gain teh abilities to do it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:15:55] <Torin|_> and then there will be people who focus on those spiritual abilities, one person might be able to go into the spiritual world, but has to come out where he started
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:16:34] <Torin|_> another person might be able to walk past an area where there were aggressive monsters in the physical world and pull his physical body forward to where his spiritual body traveled, and then re-enter the physical world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:16:41] <Torin|_> essentially bypassing something someone else would have to fight through
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:17:26] <Torin|_> also there are stats for each reality, so you not only need abilities to interact with these other realities, but the stats to back them up
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:17:49] <Torin|_> the main thing I need to think of, is how do you make a classless system that is balanced
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:18:16] <Torin|_> I was also thinking of doing classes like a game I recently played
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:18:25] <Torin|_> that your class is assigned to you based on what skills you have and what skills you use most
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:18:38] <Torin|_> so its kind of like a "bonus template" that is tacked on top of your abilities
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 04, 20:19:19] <Torin|_> so you're not necessarily limited in what skills or spells you have, but which ones you choose and use most determine whet class the game puts you in, and which bonuses you get

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 18:49:14] <Torin|_> that nation decides your race, but it also decides a template that is laid over your race
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 18:49:50] <Torin|_> so there could be elves from two different nations with totally different modifiers, but also restrictions
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 18:50:17] <Torin|_> like one elven nations could have banned the use of arcane magic completely, so elves from a certain nation would not have any access to arcane magic or be able to participate in training arcane magic in any way

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 19:22:01] <Torin|_> so how did titan quest work jarza?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 19:26:42] <Torin|_> sounds similiar to what we had in mind but implemented the limitations of what you can learn in a different way
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 19:29:19] <Torin|_> our idea was that you pick a nation, that puts you into a specific race with certain restrictions on what general skill groups you can use
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 19:29:48] <Torin|_> from there, you pick skills you want to focus on and learn, and by learning them, you unlock access to other new skills, and prevent learning other skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 19:30:28] <Torin|_> so you focus on basic arcane magic, that might unlock advanced arcaen magic and divine magic, but prevent access to combat skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 19:30:55] <Torin|_> then you learn thieving skills, but that disables being able to learn divine magic
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 19:31:44] <Torin|_> well in a way, rather than picking 2 core groups of skills to advance skills in, you narrow your selection down to a few core skills by advancing certain ones

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:07:09] <Torin|_> but why would you want two trainers for the same skills?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:07:26] <Torin|_> ok, every trainer you enlist with will prevent you from training some specific skill
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:08:01] <Torin|_> if there are 3 thief trainers, each with a different skill they disable, then obviously you'll want to pick one that does not disable a skill you also want to train
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:08:55] <Torin|_> when you picka  trainer, you are also effectively preventing yourself from learning a skill
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:09:18] <Torin|_> which skill you want to disable will depend on which trainer you pick
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:09:41] <Torin|_> to prevent people from learning everything
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:09:54] <Torin|_> the more skill choices you make, the less options you have for learning new skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 08, 20:10:03] <Torin|_> until you basically limit yourself to a specific set of skills

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 09, 22:17:53] <Torin|> the third skill requires you have at least 2 skills at 50% or higher

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 09, 23:23:28] <Torin|_> well, you get stats higher by using skills associated with them :)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 09, 23:23:57] <Torin|_> using a strength based axe skill will grow the axe skill and grow your strength

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 09, 23:31:44] <Torin|_> but also, using will not be the only way to grow skills, one aspect of teh mud that faisel strongly wants is a system for people to grow without actively playing
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 09, 23:31:58] <Torin|_> like you can leave your character in the guild to train a skill for 3 days and come back 3 days later and you'll have made progress

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:25:12] <Torin|_> your race is determined by your nation of origin, which implies some specific restrictions on which guilds you can join
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:25:39] <Torin|_> the world is based on 3 "layers", a physical, spiritual and mental layer
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:25:47] <Torin|_> the physical can be viewed as the master layer
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:26:00] <Torin|_> "pull back a veil" to access the spiritual world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:26:16] <Torin|_> most being are physical and spiritual in nature, and players can project their spiritual self intot eh spiritual world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:26:29] <Torin|_> its a separate world, framed by the physical world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:26:54] <Torin|_> when physical+spiritual beings die, their spiritual essence is separated from their physical body, and their spirit roams the spirit world
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:27:20] <Torin|_> the mental is a unifying part of teh whole equation
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:27:36] <Torin|_> your core essence is mental, when you die, that is all you are, until you rejoin yhour physical+spiritual bodies
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:28:06] <Torin|_> there is also a mental combat system, your mind can be attacked, and it has its own health/mana stats
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:28:13] <Torin|_> just as your physical and spiritual bodies do
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:28:29] <Torin|_> there is no "mental world", it is kind of like a void that your thoughts exist in when separated from your body
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:28:43] <Torin|_> the mental side is what facilitates the global chat stuff
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:29:01] <Torin|_> there is also some presence in the void that you can use to revive yourself if no player is around to do it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:29:16] <Torin|_> I dont know, thats some of the stuff we talked about
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:29:33] <Torin|_> yoru skills and spells grow in power when you use them, your stats grow by using associated skills and spells
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 10, 20:29:57] <Torin|_> there is a system to allow you to train/perform some job while offline, so your character growth can continue, albeit at a slower pace

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:30:00] <Torin|> the idea of "normal" attacks and manual attacks is kind of going out the window
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:30:10] <Torin|> well in the imperial sense
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:30:43] <Torin|> if you want to do nothing but punch instead of normal attacks, you can do that, basically you tell the game what your default attack command is
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:30:57] <Torin|> weapon speeds will be based on a number of things
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:31:06] <Torin|> the attack skill you use will be one of those
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:31:13] <Torin|> weapon used will be the base
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:31:31] <Torin|> depending on the weapon, a stat will influence the attack speed
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:31:42] <Torin|> then the final modifier will be the attack skill itself
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:31:54] <Torin|> bigger/stronger attacks will be slower than the normal default attack you start with
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:32:06] <Torin|> and take more endurance or move points or whatever the stat is
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:32:23] <Torin|> the basic system works like a loop
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:32:32] <Torin|> you join a fight, and your default attack command starts to loop
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:32:42] <Torin|> it waits X seconds based on the skill's execution time, then goes
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:32:46] <Torin|> after it going, the loop starts over
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:32:52] <Torin|> you can interrupt the loop with a different skill
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:33:18] <Torin|> and basically, you interrupt the loop, a new skill's execution time starts, when its done, the skill goes, and the default attack loop resumes
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:34:00] <Torin|> there will be a "normal" attack skill, no damage modifier, no attack speed modifier, lowest stat cost, lowest execution time
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:34:26] <Torin|> but you choose how you want to attack
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:34:35] <Torin|> since you don't do normal attacks and manual attacks at the same time
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:34:40] <Torin|> its up to you to decide how you want to fight
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:35:58] <Torin|> well, if you buffer multiple manual commands, it will execute them in order
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:36:02] <Torin|> is that what you mean?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:36:32] <Torin|> you won't see a "you're too busy to do that!"
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:36:33] <Torin|> or whatever
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:36:55] <Torin|> also, faisel wants to leave it up to guild writers to design the attack method they want for their skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:37:17] <Torin|> which basically means rewriting the combat code every time a new guild is written
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:37:27] <Torin|> but he wants people to have flexibility to design differennt "ways" of fighting
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:37:30] <Torin|> what I outline was just 1 way
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:37:33] <Torin|> outlined*
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:38:07] <Torin|> that the combat system in design is not static
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:38:19] <Torin|> that each guild has literally a different way of executing their skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:38:42] <Torin|> they can share some or all elements with another guild, but they dont have to
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:39:14] <Torin|> that example is just one I came up with when we were talking
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:39:40] <Torin|> the only constant factor is that weapons have attack speeds and that the system is real time
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:39:51] <Torin|> how someone goes about designing how their skills function is up to them
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:43:44] <Torin|> I'll be designing essentially the playerfile in regards to combat, 1 guild, 1 area and how the system works
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:43:52] <Torin|> and actually, I'm mostly done with 2 of those
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 16:44:01] <Torin|> once I'm done, he'll code it in and we'll have a working combat system

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:49:50] <Torin|> but even the non-coding version of area making is being designed to be as wide open as possible
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:50:05] <Torin|> part of the exit syntax is whether or not it should display in the obvious exits list :)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:50:41] <Torin|> also, directions are limited to any alpha numeric string with no spaces
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:50:48] <Torin|> so you dont need to have areas with n/e/s/w/u/d
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:50:54] <Torin|> your directions could be 1/2/3/4/5
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:51:12] <Torin|> up red/blue/green/yellow/purple
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:51:18] <Torin|> whatever you want
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:51:31] <Torin|> exit <direction: alpha numeric, space separated, first value is obvious exit name, use "-" for no obvious exit><tab><destination: alpha numeric, no space><tab><extra description: alpha numeric><carriage return>
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:52:17] <Torin|> can also use multiple keywords for direction
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:52:30] <Torin|> per direction
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:52:39] <Torin|> to avoid spam
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:52:51] <Torin|> first direction in the list is obvious exit, unless -, then it shows nothing
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 16, 23:54:33] <Torin|> there are no room numbers, instead, uises room IDs, alpha numeric, no spaces, unique to the area
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:03:01] <Torin|> heh

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:10:03] <Torin|> the only thing that you need to do is come up with a syntax to control it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:10:16] <Torin|> thats another thing, every area can have a different syntax for stuff like loading mobs

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:11:57] <Torin|> and write your rooms in your format
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:12:24] <Torin|> that's the major idea behind a lot of the design of his code
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:12:39] <Torin|> you determine how you want thinsg to work, and you write the stuff that hooks into the engine
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:12:48] <Torin|> it could be simple text, it could be c++ code
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 17, 00:12:52] <Torin|> it all hooks into the same engine

#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:20:16] <Torin|> I really never use it, because most of my strategy is about what skills I want to use and which uniosn I want to take down first, and less about who is engaging who, because my unions move fast enough not to be intercepted
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:21:05] <Torin|> and usually I'm always trying to train one specific skills, so I pick my targets based on skill choices more than anything
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:21:16] <Torin|> specific set of*
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:22:44] <Torin|> one basic thing to understand is the options it gives you for each union, are based on a combination of what options the leader has (and has enough AP to use) and to a lesser extent, what the rest of your union can do
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:22:49] <Torin|> the last remnant
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:24:14] <Torin|> most choices are based on what skills the leader has, and usually you might get a choice or two of skill selection that only one or more union members have, but not your leader
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:24:19] <Torin|> but its biased towards leader selection
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:24:24] <Torin|> which is why union composition is important
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:25:31] <Torin|> if your leader has a bunch of mystic arts but your members have only combat arts, well, you're not going to get effective commands often
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:25:59] <Torin|> if you have high total AP, you will get a command "Give it all you got!" which tells everyone to use their stronges ability regardless of them being the same kind of skills
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:26:21] <Torin|> but generally, you want to group like-characters together offensively and like-characters defensively
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:26:51] <Torin|> so unions usually get designations... like "this is my mystic union" "these are my 3 physical unions"
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:27:08] <Torin|> how far int the story did you get?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:29:01] <Torin|> the first little mini quest?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:29:04] <Torin|> with blocter?
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:29:14] <Torin|> heh
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:29:28] <Torin|> yeah those first few missions before you can start making real choices kind of suck :)
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:29:36] <Torin|> its even harder on hard mode
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:29:44] <Torin|> sometimes have to redo the fight 20 times just to beat it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:31:04] <Torin|> but generally speaking, you shoudl try to kill the 2 groups of support bandits
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:31:12] <Torin|> they die easier
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:31:44] <Torin|> one thing to understand about healing though, and commands in general, is some of them break deadlock
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:32:29] <Torin|> deadlock is basically two unions engaged to fight one another, if you want to break away to do nothing but heal (which is what blocter will do if you tell him to heal), then they are out of deadlock and not engaging any enemy, so an enemy that attacks them engages in raidlock, which is basically deadlock that lowers your morale
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:32:55] <Torin|> lower morale = higher enemy damage and lower damage you do
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:33:13] <Torin|> you can save it right before then and just redo the fight
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:33:20] <Torin|> of course it helps to know where the fight starts
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:33:28] <Torin|> its basically after you round the corner past the treasure chest
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:33:43] <Torin|> once you see the world map teleporter on the left, save, then a few steps forward will start the fight
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:34:52] <Torin|> asuto save helps
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:35:51] <Torin|> depends on how hard you suck :P
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:36:01] <Torin|> but hard mode is another ballgame, but only near teh beginning
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:36:11] <Torin|> once you get past the beginning introduction crap, you have a lot mo re control
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:36:30] <Torin|> auto save triggers after every area change, every fight
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:36:43] <Torin|> and if you know a fight is coming, can manually save right before it
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:37:33] <Torin|> just use AP on combat arts on those support unions, then focus on the main union and heal as needed
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:37:42] <Torin|> rush's union can help and fight, since it has more than 1 member
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:37:52] <Torin|> heal*
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:38:14] <Torin|> blocter is in a union by himself, so telling him to heal will break deadlock and sacrifice morale when he gets raidlocked
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:38:29] <Torin|> also, you can break deadlock to heal with 1 union and re-engage the target with another union to prevent raidlock
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:38:57] <Torin|> but dont be afraid to break deadlock if you need to, the game warns you every time you try, but its not always a bad thing
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:39:11] <Torin|> you can tell by the icons to the left of the command, if it has a red glow around it, that is a deadlock breaker
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:40:11] <Torin|> breaking deadlock to heal pretty much guarantees you get to heal without them attacking first, which can be the diff between life and death
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:40:26] <Torin|> with the possible consequence of being raidlocked
#Philocommands.log:[2009 09 23, 21:40:52] <Torin|> morale control is important, most fights are determined by it even if you arent actively influencing it
